In the second gate of being subsumed within the one mind, this gate actually contains many meanings, and is divided into two parts:
First, the gate of tracing back the branches to the root; second, the gate of the root and branches supporting each other, beginning with The TathÄgata, in this...
First, based on the three contemplations in the treatise, the first is about the characteristics and truths, which corresponds to the second contemplation of the ultimate truth.
The treatise states: What is the distinction of the ultimate truth?
Thus, realizing the ultimate truth, one attains liberation from that contemplation.
This clarifies the purpose of cultivating contemplation.

Because the ultimate truth is the nature of dependent origination. If one sees the nature of dependent origination, one is liberated from the bonds of conditions, so one cultivates that contemplation.
Although the treatise says that all are created by the one mind, it takes the one mind that creates as the object, so it is called the contemplation of the ultimate truth.
The treatise says it is only the one mind because the entire three realms only revolve around the mind.
This statement is general.
Transformation has the meaning of arising and creating, as well as the meaning of transformation.
However, this single text is cited by all teachings to prove that it is mind-only.
How can one mind create the three realms?
In brief, there are three meanings:
First, those of the two vehicles think there are external objects and do not understand that they are only mind.
Even if they hear of one mind, they only think of the one of true suchness, or think that it is transformed by the mind, not all of it being mind.
Second, the one mind of the retribution consciousness is called one mind, because it distinguishes from external objects and therefore speaks of one mind.
Third, the one mind of the intrinsically pure nature of the tathÄgatagarbha is called one mind, because the principle has no two natures.
The bodhisattvas do not contemplate this first one mind.

The latter two one minds are what the sÅ«tra intends to clarify, which is common to the three contemplations. The first contemplation is based on the intrinsically pure one mind, and the latter two contemplations are common to these two minds.
The latter two one minds are briefly like the questions and explanations, and there are ten in detail:
The first of these one-sided doctrines is that of the existence of real external objects, which are only transformed by mind.
The remaining nine doctrines are all one-sided doctrines of mind only.

The second one-sided doctrine is that of the existence of both images and seeing, which is common to the eight consciousnesses and their mental activities, as well as to the seen and seeing parts of the images transformed by the consciousnesses, which are complete in the form of the original and its reflections.

As a result of the power of perfuming by the members of the dependent co-arising, the consciousnesses transform and manifest the three realms of existence, the bodies of sentient beings and their container worlds, as is explained in detail in such treatises as the MahÄyÄnasaá¹ƒgraha and VijÃ±aptimÄtratÄsiddhi.

The third one-sided doctrine is that of the return of the seen to the seer, which is common to the seeing part of the consciousnesses and their mental activities. The seen part of the images transformed by the consciousnesses is not born from separate seeds. The seeing consciousness is born and arises with the image of the seen part. This doctrine is explained in detail in the Saá¹ƒdhinirmocana SÅ«tra, the VimsatikÄ, and the Ä€lambanaparÄ«ká¹£Ä.

The fourth one-sided doctrine is that of the return of the mental activities to the mind, which is common only to the eight consciousnesses, because the mental activities have no substance apart from the consciousnesses and are also transformations of the consciousnesses, as the MadhyÄntavibhÄga says.

Fifth, it is said that there is only one mind because the branches are returned to the root, that is, the seven evolving consciousnesses are the different functions of the fundamental consciousness and have no separate substance of their own.
The Laá¹…kÄvatÄra SÅ«tra says, The ocean of store consciousness always abides, moved by the winds of objects, with waves of various consciousnesses leaping and evolving.

Since it is said that apart from water there are no waves, it is clear that apart from the fundamental consciousness there are no other first seven consciousnesses.

Seventh, because of the fusion of nature and characteristics, it is said to be one mind. This means that the tathÄgatagarbha as a whole follows conditions to accomplish all things, yet its own nature is originally neither produced nor extinguished. This principle and phenomena are completely fused without obstruction. Therefore, the one mind and the two truths are all unobstructed.
The Awakening of Faith says, Based on the Dharma of one mind, there are two kinds of gates, up to and including being inseparable.
Also, the Secret Adornment Sutra says, The Buddha says that the tathÄgatagarbha is the Älaya, and the analogy of gold and a finger ring, and so forth.
Also, the ÅšrÄ«mÄlÄ-sÅ«tra says, The intrinsically pure mind, defiled while undefiled, is difficult to understand.

All clarify that the intrinsically pure mind follows defilement, and the whole body becomes conventional, which is the arising and ceasing aspect. The defiled nature is always pure, originally true and pure, which is the aspect of suchness.

This means that the defiled aspect of purity does not obstruct the true and always accords with the conventional, and the pure aspect of defilement does not destroy the conventional and always accords with the true. Therefore, it does not obstruct the single mind and both truths are present. Contemplate deeply, there is meaning.

Eighth, it is said that there is one mind because phenomena interpenetrate, meaning that because the nature of mind is perfectly fused and unobstructed, and because the nature forms phenomena, phenomena are also fused and do not obstruct each other.
One enters all, in one there is understanding of the immeasurable, etc., each dust mote contains the Dharma realm, and gods, humans, and asuras do not leave a single dust mote.

The tenth is called one mind because of the unobstructedness of the Indra's net, meaning that within one there are all, and within all there are again all, with layers upon layers being inexhaustible, all because the nature of the mind consciousness tathÄgatagarbha is perfectly fused and inexhaustible.
The first of the above ten is a small teaching, the next three involve the provisional, the next three are based on the real, and the last three are about the unique aspects of the perfect teaching.
If the following is the same as the other vehicles, it is universally unobstructed.
The great purport of the entire text is not just this chapter. Each of the individual gates forms a different contemplation, which can be sought in vain.
Second, the gate of basis and derivative.
From here to the end of the ten gates, all are distinctions of conventional truth.
Since the characteristics of conditions are originally quiescent, one should only contemplate the truth. Why then also contemplate the distinctions of conventional truth?
The treatise says: In accordance with the contemplation of conventional truth, one enters the ultimate truth. Therefore.
The conventional serves as the explanation for the truth. Only by understanding the naturelessness of the conventional can one see the truth.
The Zhonglun says: If one does not know the conventional truth, one cannot attain the ultimate truth.
This contemplation has six aspects:
First, the contemplation of what is defiled and the basis of defilement, which simultaneously clarifies the supported and the basis, encompassing this half of the chapter.
Second, the contemplation of causes, because it contemplates the causes of defilement, encompassing the next two chapters.
Third, the contemplation of encompassing faults, because it is exclusively about suffering and its causes.
Fourth, the contemplation of guarding against faults, because it guards against the false views of ordinary people.
Fifth, the contemplation of non-disgust and disgust, because it prevents the arrogance of the Lesser Vehicle.
The above three contemplations each encompass one chapter in sequence.
Sixth, the profound contemplation, which reveals the wondrous principle of dependent origination that surpasses conceptual grasping.
This encompasses the last three chapters.

Among the six contemplations, the first two establish the characteristics of defilement, the next one contemplates the faults within defilement, the next two contemplate correctly to prevent errors, and the last one is the profound culmination of contemplative practice.

Now, this half gate is the contemplation of the basis of defilement. The conditioned factors of dependent origination are defiled, but these defiled characteristics are based on one mind. Therefore, the treatise says: This is the distinction between the two truths.

Because pure reality does not arise alone, and delusion alone is not established. The true reality of one mind and the conventional reality of defilement - these two combine to have the accumulation of dependent origination.
There are three parts in the sutra:
First, the general, which refers to distinguishing the twelve based on one mind, then the twelve are upheld by one mind.
But it specifically says the TathÄgata speaks because the sudden completeness of one mind is not known by anyone but the Buddha.
It means that the TathÄgata has already realized the nature of conditions in the past, and the characteristics are equal and continuous. It is transmitted and explained in succession.
Next, the meaning of the question is:
The twelve links of dependent origination are arranged in the three times, and they arise in sequence.
Why is it now said that they are all based on one mind?
Later, there is no separate explanation in the treatise. The ancient masters only say that apart from the mind of the fundamental consciousness, everything is not established.
Although this does not lose the meaning of support, it is not yet grasping the essence.
Now, I say that the skillful demonstrator shows that not only the three times are not apart from the true mind.

Now, a single thought suddenly contains the twelve, further revealing that the past and future are not apart from the one mind, this is the same as the ninth chapter of the Abhidharma-koÅ›a explaining the twelve links of dependent origination in a single moment.
Therefore, this one gate contains many dependent originations:
One contains the two kinds of dependent origination in the Laá¹…kÃ¢vatÄra-sÅ«tra.
The second says: If briefly explained, dependent origination is twofold:
First, the dependent origination of discriminating self-nature, which refers to the arising of dharmas based on the Älaya-vijÃ±Äna, which is now the support of the one mind;

Second, the dependent origination of discriminating the desirable and undesirable, which refers to the twelve links of dependent origination, which can discriminate the desirable and undesirable in good and evil destinies, because of being the nature of conditions for various kinds of bodies, which generally includes the present text and the following nine sections.
The second includes the four kinds of dependent origination in the ninth chapter of the Abhidharma-koÅ›a:
First, momentary; second, continuous; third, positional; fourth, distant continuation.
The latter three are common to the other nine gates. This is the first one here.
It says, What is momentary?
It refers to the twelve factors in a moment, such as killing out of greed.
Their extensive explanation of the characteristics is largely the same as this, so it is not necessary to rely on the sequence now. The meaning is to show that they are suddenly complete in one mind.
Following the matter of greed and being born together with the mind generally refers to the matters that are carried out.

The matters of greed are not one, but taking any one matter, in a single thought it is complete with twelve. This means that carrying out this matter of greed must rely on the mind to arise, and also to understand the previous object, so the mind is the factor of consciousness.
The matter is the practitioner's action. The matter of greed is the action of the mental activity. If it takes shape in the body or speech, it is also the two actions.
Not knowing the fault of greed that can attract suffering is called confusion about the action.
Name-and-form arises together with ignorance and mind means that name-and-form is the general term, and it is the support for the two, name and the arising together.
Therefore the Jin edition of the sutra says: The place where consciousness depends is called name-and-form.
The Abhidharma-koÅ›a says: The three aggregates that arise together with consciousness are collectively called name-and-form.
The meaning is clear: because the aggregate of feeling is itself the link of feeling.

Name-and-form increases to become the six sense bases means that without producing the five consciousnesses, it is only called the ten elements; when the five consciousnesses are produced in dependence, it is called the ten sense bases.
The manifestation of the basis of consciousness is precisely the increase; the word increase should be translated as manifestation.

The Abhidharma-koÅ›a says: Abiding in the faculties of name-and-form is called the six sense bases, meaning that the six sense faculties are the distinctions, and by distinguishing the general into six, it is called abiding in name-and-form.
Craving must confront an object to become contact, and feeling must experience contact. Craving is precisely attachment, called feeling without satiation.
The grasping of desire is the grasping of craving, because craving and grasping moisten the six factors of existence and bring about existence.
But the various factors of existence that arise are themselves existence.ğŸ”½That which has arisen is the arising of the various factors, which is itself birth.
Aging is the maturation of birth, because things that are born immediately change.
Death is the destruction of aging, because of momentariness.
Moreover, according to the MahÄyÄna, it is because of the destruction of characteristics. Therefore the sÅ«tra says: From the very beginning there is cessation, but it is not taught to the foolish.
If this is not severed, it is called continuous bondage.
The five aggregates in the state of the twelve factors are all called states.
This is the distant continuation that has existed since beginningless time.
The principles of the great and small vehicles are generally the same, but the differences are in the sixth and eighth consciousnesses.
If it is not the valid cognition of the holy teachings, who would believe this principle?
The author of the treatise does not understand, and it is almost as if he has neglected it.
This text correctly distinguishes the twelve factors of existence that are simultaneous but have different natures.

If the twelve members are simultaneous and of the same substance, they are also the twelve members. That is, delusion concerning ultimate truth is ignorance, and that which is possessed and has outflows is called karmic forces, which are the same as consciousness and also the same as name-and-form, which is the same as the mental faculty. Encountering objects is contact, experiencing objects is feeling, being attached to objects is craving, grasping objects is grasping, and inviting retribution is becoming. The actualization of the substance is birth, and the same as old age and death is aging and death.
These twelve members are explained in terms of time in six ways.

First, the twelve members are explained in terms of the five periods. That is, past ignorance and karmic forces arise from past afflictions in the past. This is afflictions giving rise to delusions and karma.
The two causes in the past give rise to the five effects in the present, which is delusions and karma giving rise to suffering.
If the present gives rise to the future, and the future gives rise to the future again, then suffering gives rise to suffering again.
This is based on the three periods of time to infer causes and seek effects, provisionally speaking of five, not based on mutual dependence, not falling into endlessness.
The second is based on the three times, the third on the two times, and the fourth on the one time, established in sequence, all as explained in the first gate.
The fifth is simultaneous with different substances, and the sixth is simultaneous with the same substance, which is like this text.

Second, in the contemplation of following along with great compassion, it corresponds to the second seeking liberation elsewhere, referring to ordinary beings who are foolish and inverted, who should always seek liberation in the Älaya consciousness and ÄdÄnavijÃ±Äna, and seek liberation elsewhere in the self and what belongs to the self.

The sÅ«tra clarifies that it is only one mind, and outside of the mind there are no dharmas of self, which should be sought within the one mind, also the same as the VimalakÄ«rti SÅ«tra saying the liberation of the buddhas should be sought in the mental activities of sentient beings.
It says Älaya, which means storehouse consciousness, because it is able to store all defiled dharmas and prevent their loss, and because the view of self and attachment grasp it as their inner self.
This name only applies to ordinary beings and those still learning.
Ä€laya means grasping and holding, because it grasps and holds the seeds and the material sense organs.
This name is common to all states.

These two are different names for mind. The meaning of the treatise master's main clarification of mind containing both defilement and purity is to raise both names together to explain the meaning of one mind.
What is the meaning of seeking?
If there is a grasping of self, it becomes the Älaya. If the grasping of self is eliminated, then it abandons the name of Älaya.
Only the ÄdÄnavijÃ±Äna holds the pure seeds, and then the false mind is extinguished and the true mind manifests.
Therefore, the verse below says, If the mind is extinguished, then birth and death end, which is the extinction of the false, not the extinction of the essence of the mind.
Third, in terms of the observation of the cognition of all aspects, it corresponds to the second observation of the basis, clarifying that this dependent arising is based on two kinds:
First, based on the ultimate truth, as already explained above.
Second, based on the mind and consciousness, which is the present text.
The previous [discussion] was only in terms of the pure [aspect], while this [discussion] includes both the defiled and pure [aspects]. The meaning of basis is as explained above.
Moreover, the previous [section] directly relies on the true to give rise to the false, while this [section] reveals that the false is based on the true.
The third [section on] the mutual assistance of their own actions also has three [parts]:
First, regarding the contemplation of the characteristics and truths, the following two sections correspond to the contemplation of causes.
There are two kinds of contemplation of causes:
1. Contemplation of other causes, 2. Contemplation of one's own causes.
Yuan Gong says:
Because the activities are different from ignorance, they are called other causes.
From the previous ignorance, later ignorance arises, which is called one's own cause.
Other causes are slightly inclusive, while one's own causes have obstructions.

Because the treatise says, 'The contemplation of one's own causes is the absence of later branches apart from the previous branches,' and the sÅ«tra says, 'The condition of ignorance is able to give rise to activities.'
Now, regarding other causes, they completely rely on the previous branches to give rise to later branches, thus distinguishing them from their own natures.
In the contemplation of great compassion, the contemplation of all characteristics is called a method.
Because it only arises from ignorance and gives rise to karmic formations, it is called its own cause, distinguishing it from other causes that can give rise to karmic formations.
It is just like how curd definitely arises from milk and not from stone.
The great compassion contemplation breaks down the causes such as the Almighty, and the wisdom of all aspects manifests the characteristics of dependent origination.
The three contemplations have slightly different intentions but the meaning of the text is largely the same. The virtuous ones do not examine the text and mistakenly give different explanations.
This one approach is precisely the contemplation of other causes.
The sutra clarifies that each has two karmic activities, one is its own activity and the other is assisting in completion.
But both are called other because ignorance confuses the object and only then becomes the cause of karmic formations. If one understands the object, how can deluded karmic activity arise?
Moreover, the first clarifies its own activity, revealing the meaning of being other;
the second clarifies giving rise to what follows, revealing the meaning of being a cause.
The remaining eleven factors should be contemplated in this way.

However, the cause of birth is the condition as cause, because condition is called cause in the sense of the general meaning. Among the four conditions, the dominant condition definitely exists in the mutual relationship of the members.

The Scripture on the Theory of Causality and this text only clarify the dominant condition, and the existence or nonexistence of the other three conditions is indefinite, and therefore they are not discussed.

That is, craving, in relation to grasping, and becoming, in relation to birth, have the meaning of condition as cause, because craving increases and becomes grasping and consciousness increases and becomes becoming.

If the member of consciousness is the seeds of action, then the karmic forces, in relation to consciousness, also have the condition as cause, but the other members do not have the meaning of condition as cause in their mutual relationship.

The Abhidharmasamuccaya says that ignorance, in relation to the karmic forces, has the condition as cause, because it is said that the perfuming of action at the time of ignorance is associated with ignorance and is therefore metaphorically said to be ignorance. In reality, it is the seeds of the karmic forces.

The YogÄcÄrabhÅ«mi ÅšÄstra says that the members do not have the condition as cause in their mutual relationship, because it is said that the actual dharmas of craving, grasping, and becoming are only action.
The four positions are distinguished in terms of the existence of conditions. The first two are definitely real, the next one is indefinite, and the last one is a hypothetical explanation.

Ignorance and the karmic forces and craving and grasping have the other two conditions, because they are distinguished in terms of actual dharmas, because they are immediately antecedent and attract each other, and because the karmic forces, etc., and the thought of volition can retrogress and be objects of the mind.

Becoming and birth and feeling and craving have neither the condition of equal and immediate antecedence nor the condition of object, because the seeds attract the actual dharmas, and because the actual dharmas that are generated retrogress and take the seeds as objects.
The remaining members are both absent in their mutual relations.

Here we are speaking in terms of the real conditions of the members that are adjacent, in sequential order, and unmixed.ğŸ”½If we speak of conditions in a different way, that is, in terms of the reverse order and the nonsequential order, the conditions are not definite, because there is a reverse order and a nonsequential order.

Since there are many conditions and their meanings are not the same, the SÅ«tra, in order to be concise, speaks of only those that are definite, and since it speaks of causes, it includes the other three conditions.

As for the twelve links, each has its own initial activity that is no different from the previous two gates. The treatise author only explains the two activities of old age and death, because this is difficult, so he takes one to exemplify all.
However, ignorance has no cause, and old age and death have no effect. Therefore, the first eleven each serve as the cause for the arising of the subsequent links.
Old age and death have no effect. What do they serve as the cause for?

The meaning of the sutra text is evident. It shows that they serve as the cause for ignorance. Then ignorance is not without a cause, and old age and death are not without an effect. Therefore, it says because of not knowing, therefore the continuity is not cut off.
Not knowing refers to ignorance.

Therefore, the twelve links of dependent origination are like a continuous search, like a well-drawing wheel without end. This shows the opposite. If one can know, then there is no more birth and death.

The treatise author generally takes the two activities to be the cause for subsequent birth, therefore it says because of not seeing or knowing, the five aggregates of form are destroyed, and can serve as the cause for subsequent birth.
It can serve as the cause for subsequent birth, meaning that the previous aggregates merely cease and then the subsequent aggregates arise, thus the previous is the cause.
The subsequent mind does not know, which is ignorance. With ignorance as the cause, the twelve links continue without interruption.
Not seeing this mind, one vainly speaks of this and that.
Second, in terms of the contemplation of following along with great compassion, the four contemplations below clarify the third kind of heterodox path seeking liberation.

translated: The treatise says, There are three kinds of inverted causes: the cause of inherent nature, the cause of self-mastery, and the cause of ascetic practices, as well as the cause of no cause.
There are four causes here, which are refuted by the following four gates in order.
The first three are false causes, so they are collectively called inverted.
One, inherent nature refers to prakriti, which is the cause of what is known according to the SÄá¹ƒkhya school. It is believed that by knowing this prakriti, one can attain liberation.
The previous statement of seeking liberation in other places reveals that their principle is wrong. Although it is said here that it is what is known, the meaning is that the practice is wrong.
The second is that KÄlakalpa seeks the god ÄªÅ›vara as the cause of what is sought, thinking that when ÄªÅ›vara is angry, sentient beings suffer;
when ÄªÅ›vara is pleased, sentient beings are happy.
They seek his pleasure.
The third is SaÃ±jÄyin, who takes painful action as the cause of cultivation, thinking that by merely cultivating painful practices to repay past karma one can attain liberation.

The fourth is the theory of no cause, that is, Ajita, who thinks that sentient beings do not attain [liberation] by means of causes, that myriad dharmas are natural, and that if one understands this one can attain liberation.

Sentient beings seek [liberation] among these deviant causes and theories of no cause, and the sÅ«tra wishes to use the correct to refute the deviant, so it mentions these four approaches, making them seek [liberation] among them, and should not seek [liberation] among these deviant views.

This approach refutes the nature of darkness. It means that the two kinds of functions of the conditions and factors can give rise to those conditional events, not by the nature of darkness. Therefore, if the conditions of the previous factors are severed, the subsequent factors will not continue. One can attain liberation in a single lifetime. Your nature of darkness, even if extended to eighty thousand eons, still has no chance of liberation.

Third, observing from the perspective of omniscience, which corresponds to the third expedient observation. It means that each of the conditions and factors has two functions as expedients for giving rise to subsequent [factors]. If the previous [factors] are extinguished, the subsequent [factors] will not arise. This is the expedient for liberation.
In the fourth [aspect of] non-abandonment, the three approaches are the same as before.
The first, observing from the perspective of characteristics, corresponds to the observation of one's own causes.
The meaning of one's own causes has already been seen in the above text.
Moreover, the treatise says, The observation of one's own causes means observing the causes for the arising of ignorance and so forth, because of the conditions and events [involved].

It means that without the previous factors, the subsequent factors do not exist. For example, without leaving ignorance, there are the formative forces and so forth. Then ignorance is only the cause for the formative forces itself.
Because of this, it causes the practice to be uninterrupted. For this reason, it is only said to assist in completion.
If there is only practice without separation from ignorance, then it becomes too immediate, and it should not be said that ignorance is a condition for practice.
If there is practice with complete separation from ignorance, then it becomes too distant, and ignorance is not the cause of practice.
The treatise says: If different, it is not established. If not immediate and not separate, it is called the self-cause.
It is also established with two meanings.

Therefore, the treatise master quotes a verse from the Madhyamaka-Å›Ästra, which says: The dharmas produced by various conditions are not identical with the cause, and are also not different from the cause. They are neither annihilated nor eternal.
The first line is a general statement.
The next line says that because it is what is produced, it is not the producer.
And are also not different from the cause means that from the producer, the produced is born.
Neither annihilated nor eternal means that because they are not identical, they are not eternal. Because they are not different, they are not annihilated.
Also, because it is not identical to the cause, the effect is not annihilated, and because the cause is not different, the cause is not permanent.
Also, because it is not identical, cause and effect are both not annihilated, and because they are not different, cause and effect are both not permanent, not without cause or permanent.
Also, it is the opposite of this, not permanent due to continuity.
Also, because it is not separate, it is not identical, so it is not permanent but not annihilated. Contemplate this.
In the text, first it is in the forward order, then in the reverse order.
In the forward order, the text says ignorance has two kinds:
one is the time of the seed, the other is the time of the fruit.
Here, the time of the seed causes action to not be annihilated, because there are two kinds of meanings.

As for demonstrating the matter of conditions, the seed is the seed, and the fruit is the present activity. Although the fruit of present activity has already passed away, it is not taken. Because the seed continues, it causes action to not be annihilated. Because it can assist in accomplishing action, it takes the time of the seed.
It can also be said that the initial arising of ignorance is called the seed, and when it evolves to the stage of karmic formations it is called the fruit.

Due to the power of the previous stage of attraction, it causes the karmic formations to be uninterrupted and assists in the formation of karmic formations, so it is biased towards the time of the seed.
The other eleven factors both have two times, which can be understood by analogy.

As for the latter reverse contemplation, the treatise says, The past and future are extinguished, and the present is also non-existent, therefore it is not said. The twelve links of dependent arising do not go beyond the three periods of time. Since the past and future do not exist, how can the present exist?
Therefore, it is not said that there is the meaning of being uninterrupted and assisting in the formation.
Moreover, the reason it is not said is because extinction extinguishes the previous meanings, so it does not need to be said that there are differences such as seed and fruit.
Second, in the contemplation of following along with great compassion to destroy the inverted causes, the self-sovereign heaven is taken as the cause of sentient beings.
Now, using ignorance, etc. as the cause of karmic formations, etc., it does not even come from the other links, how could it come from the self-sovereign?
Third, in terms of observing with the cognition of all aspects, this corresponds to the fourth observation of the characteristics of causes and conditions.

As for because the factors of existence are uncreated, since the previous ones cause the later ones to not cease and assist in accomplishing the later ones, then the later ones have no nature. How can the previous ones create the later ones?
This very uncreatedness is the characteristic of conditions, which is the realm of the cognition of all aspects.
Fifth, the three paths are not severed.

One, based on the characteristics and truths in the treatise, within the six observations, it is called the observation of encompassing faults, which means using the three paths to encompass the twelve factors. Then it is shown that the factors of existence only encompass the faults of the causes and effects of suffering. Karmic actions and afflictions are the causes, and suffering is the effect. There is also the forward and reverse [order].
In the initial forward observation, the text contains two meanings:
